messages.content:
You are an expert in propaganda analysis. Analyze the following text. 
Always keep in mind that you are only looking for russian propaganda, not any other type of propaganda. Any other type of propaganda should be ignored and labeled as "No Propaganda".

Text:
"With Arab audiences , Kremlin propaganda plays an effective game : \" If America can flaunt international norms , why can't Putin do it ? \" , Or \" Ukraine is a Russian province that the West egged on against Russia . \" \" When did the West ever face consequences for the Iraq war , Palestine ? \""

1. Identify the main label that best describes the text.
2. Identify the high-level category that best describes the text.

Main labels:
‚Ä¢ main label 1 ‚Äî Loaded language: Use emotionally charged or stereotyped wording to sway feelings.  
‚Ä¢ main label 2 ‚Äî Appeal to fear/prejudice: Try to persuade by warning of frightening outcomes or playing on biases.  
‚Ä¢ main label 3 ‚Äî Doubt: Undermine credibility by questioning motives, facts, or sources.  
‚Ä¢ main label 4 ‚Äî Name calling/labeling: Attack a person or group with insulting or demeaning labels.  
‚Ä¢ main label 5 ‚Äî Flag-waving: Justify a position by appealing to patriotism or group identity.  
‚Ä¢ main label 6 ‚Äî Exaggeration or minimization: Overstate benefits/harms or downplay them to mislead.  
‚Ä¢ main label 7 ‚Äî Causal oversimplification: Claim a simple cause for a complex issue or outcome.  
‚Ä¢ main label 8 ‚Äî Red herring: Introduce an irrelevant point to distract from the main issue.  
‚Ä¢ main label 9 ‚Äî Black-and-white fallacy: Present only two options and ignore reasonable alternatives.  
‚Ä¢ main label 10 ‚Äî Reductio ad hitlerum: Dismiss an idea by associating it with Nazis/Hitler or similarly reviled groups.  
‚Ä¢ main label 11 ‚Äî Appeal to authority: Cite an authority‚Äôs support as proof rather than evidence.  
‚Ä¢ main label 12 ‚Äî Straw man: Misrepresent an opponent‚Äôs argument, then refute the weaker version.  
‚Ä¢ main label 13 ‚Äî Thought-terminating clich√©s: Use stock phrases that shut down questioning or debate.  
‚Ä¢ main label 14 ‚Äî Whataboutism: Deflect criticism by accusing others of similar or worse behavior.  
‚Ä¢ main label 15 ‚Äî Slogans: Use a short, catchy phrase to promote an idea.  
‚Ä¢ main label 16 ‚Äî Bandwagon: Argue something is good/true because it‚Äôs popular or widely adopted.  
‚Ä¢ main label 17 ‚Äî Repetition: Repeat the same claim or phrase many times to make it stick.  
‚Ä¢ main label 18 ‚Äî no_propaganda: No relevant propaganda detected.  

High-level categories:

High-level category 1: Patriotic & Catchy Appeals  
    Contains main labels: 5, 15  

High-level category 2: Popularity Appeals  
    Contains main labels: 16  

High-level category 3: Deflections & Distractions  
    Contains main labels: 14, 17, 7, 8  

High-level category 4: Emotional & Loaded Persuasion  
    Contains main labels: 1, 2, 4, 6, 10, 11  

High-level category 5: Argument Manipulations  
    Contains main labels: 12, 13, 3, 9  

High-level category 6: No Propaganda  
    Contains main labels: 18  

Now return the labels in a JSON format with the following structure:
{{"main": integer,"high": integer}}

Follow the json format strictly. Do not add any additional text or explanations. Just use the integers for labeling, no strings.
Remember to always return Integers only! Only return one integer that best describes the text. Never return multiple integers or a list of integers!
{"main": 14, "high": 3}
